description: CRITICAL: Legacy code that is not used by any other code or front-end interfaces (CLI, MCP, web) should be removed. Unused code increases maintenance burden, creates confusion, and violates YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It) principle.

do.description: Remove unused code and keep codebase lean
content: Delete classes/modules that are not imported anywhere
Remove functions/methods that are never called
Eliminate code not used by CLI, MCP, or other front-end interfaces
Keep only code that is actively used or referenced
Correct Examples (clean codebase):
- All classes are imported and used by other modules
- All functions are called from somewhere in the codebase
- All modules are referenced by CLI, MCP, or test code
- No orphaned files or dead code paths
Legacy Code Detection Requirements:
- Class/module must be imported by at least one other module
- Function/method must be called from production or test code
- Code must be accessible via CLI, MCP, or other front-end
- Test-only code must be in test directories and used by tests

dont.description: Don't keep unused legacy code or orphaned modules
content: Don't keep classes that are never imported
Don't maintain functions that are never called
Don't preserve modules not used by any front-end interface
Don't leave commented-out code 'for future use'
Wrong Examples (legacy code):
class Router:
def determine_next_action_from_state(self, state_file):
# ... implementation ...
(class exists but never imported or used)
def legacy_helper_function():
# Old implementation
pass
(function defined but never called)
# Old router implementation - kept for reference
class OldRouter:
(commented or unused code kept 'just in case')
Legacy Code Indicators (REMOVE):
- Class/module not imported by any other file
- Function/method never called (except test-only code)
- Code not accessible via CLI, MCP, or web interface
- Duplicate functionality replaced by newer implementation
- Test code for removed/deleted functionality
- Commented-out code blocks
Detection Strategy:
- Scan all Python files for class/function definitions
- Check if each class/function is imported or called
- Verify code is accessible via front-end interfaces
- Flag orphaned code for removal
Action Required:
- Remove unused classes/modules immediately
- Delete functions that are never called
- Clean up test code for removed functionality
- Use git history to retrieve deleted code if needed later
- Document removal in commit messages
